Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social and Biogeophysical Factors Contributing to Soil Fertility Sustainability in Local and Regional Food Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will employ a geographic approach focused on human-environment interactions to analyze soil fertility management and the combined social and biogeophysical factors that contribute to soil fertility sustainability in local and regional food systems. The project will focus on the complex interplay among farming philosophies, access to resources, and participation in local and regional food systems. It also will examine how these factors influence farmer decision making and soil fertility on participating farms. This project will provide new information regarding the human-environment aspects of agricultural sustainability and insight into the potential for local and regional food system activities like farmers markets to address the challenges of reducing adverse environmental impacts of food production and improving agricultural sustainability. The special attention given to phosphorus will yield new findings regarding the ability of local and regional food systems to break from dependence on non-renewable sources of fertilizer and prevent excessive application of nutrients that can damage connected ecosystems. Findings will be delivered directly to farmers and other engaged in local and regional food systems to help improve their practices as well as to sustainable farming associations and non-profits that work to connect farmers with resources needed to strengthen local and regional food systems. The results of this research therefore will advance basic scientific understanding about soil sustainability and will assist farmers, policy makers, and food system advocates as they work to ensure the long-term viability of the food system. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Soils are one of the most important resources for food production and agricultural sustainability, but many aspects of soil sustainability still are poorly understood. One of these issues is the ability of local and regional food systems to produce more sustainable soil fertility. In conducting this project, the doctoral student whose dissertation research will be supported will use semi-structured interviews, soil analysis, and geospatial techniques to answer three core questions: (1) How do farmers participating in a local and regional food systems manage their soil fertility? (2) How does participation in a local and regional food systems influence soil fertility management decisions? (3) How resilient is the soil fertility of local and regional food systems? The student will integrate information from interviews with the results of soil testing for statistical analysis to better understand how social and ecological factors interact and contribute to sustainable soil fertility. Interview analysis will identify key challenges and successes in sustainable soil management and provide greater context for statistical analysis. Geospatial techniques will be used to map and analyze degrees of farmer dependence on non-renewable fertilizers. This student will analyze regional farmers market networks based in New York City, but the research framework and findings will have applications in local and regional food systems in many other regions of North America and elsewhere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project investigated the social and environmental factors and interactions that contribute to soil fertility management and soil fertility sustainability in the context of local food system initiatives. The project focused specifically on phosphorus use and sustainability on farms in the northeastern U.S. that sell produce through a network of farmers’ markets in New York City. The project asked three primary questions: 1) How are participating farmers managing phosphorus fertility; 2) How does participation in this local food system initiative influence soil fertility management; and 3) How sustainable is phosphorus use in this system?

Farmers selling through these farmers’ markets were recruited for participation in the project beginning in the early summer of 2015 and through the early winter of 2016. Each farmer was interviewed during the winter and early spring of 2016 to explore their experiences participating in this local food system, how they manage soil fertility on their farms, and what factors influence their management practices. During this period, significant time was spent observing farmer-customer interactions at the farmers’ markets to help verify interview responses. Interviews were analyzed for important themes and common experiences. Interviews were also used to gather key demographic and statistical information about each farm.

During the 2016 growing season, soil was collected twice from every field on each participating farm, totaling approximately 230 fields across 23 farms. Soils collected in March of 2016, prior to planting, were assessed for basic chemical fertility and soil organic matter to provide a baseline for assessment. Soils collected in mid-June were assessed for biological components of phosphorus fertility, which provides a picture of ecologically-based soil fertility and the potential for farmers to break from the use of non-renewable sources of phosphorus that are commonly used in agriculture today. Sources of phosphorus fertilizers used by farmers where traced to assess the extent to which participating farms relied on non-renewable sources of phosphorus.

Participating farmers used a wide range of soil fertility practices including the use of compost and manure, cover crops, and both refined and unrefined mineral fertilizers. Approximately two-thirds of the participating farms used at least some manure and compost for their fertilizer inputs, but almost half of all participants also used phosphorus fertilizers derived directly from non-renewable sources, and one-fifth of participating farms used only these fertilizers. Furthermore, the vast majority manure and compost used on these farms was produced by animals fed conventionally grown grain, which means that the phosphorus contained in these ‘natural’ fertilizers was also derived from the same non-renewable sources.

Interviews revealed that participation in these farmers’ markets has a complex relationship with farming practices. The most significant factors in soil fertility management (and farming practice in general) is how/where a farmer learned to farm, and access to fertility resources (compost, manure, fertilizer dealers, etc.). However, farmers interviewed in this study interacted significantly with their customers, and many of them had meaningful, long-term relationship with regular customers. Through these relationships, a great deal of trust and care is developed. In some cases, this care for customers seems to translate into a growing concern for the health of their farm environments, and some farms have altered (or are currently altering) farming practices to reflect these changing views.

The results of soil analysis show clear trends whereby farms that use more compost and manure for their fertilizer needs have healthier soils that have greater potential to provide phosphorus needs through natural nutrient cycling. Unfortunately, all but one of the participating farms continues to add more phosphorus to their fields on an annual basis, regardless of the inherent fertility in the soil. This is due to a number of factors, chiefly that it is impossible to not add additional phosphorus to fields when manure is used to meet other fertilizer needs, such as nitrogen. It is also common agriculture practice to add phosphorus each year since these fertilizers have historically been inexpensive, and excess phosphorus does not negatively affect crop production. However, excessive levels of phosphorus in the soil pose a significant threat to surface and ground waters, where it can greatly increase algae growth that pollutes drinking water and kills aquatic organisms. And more than 85% of all fields sampled in this study had excessive levels of soil phosphorus.

This research project demonstrates that there is great potential for local food system initiatives to create sustainable systems of soil fertility, both through the social relations found in these systems, and through the use of compost and manure fertilizers. However, this potential is not currently realized in this case study. This is largely due not to poor practices on the part of these farmers, but to structural problems in U.S. agriculture, which relies too heavily on conventional grain and manure, which makes even organic fertilizers ultimately unsustainable.
